text: Ohara Shōson, who also worked under the pseudonyms Ohara Hōson and Ohara Koson, was one of the modern Japan’s most prolific creators of kachōga—prints depicting flowers (ka) and birds (chō). These two late prints offer different takes on the beloved rooster. One shows a rooster beneath the overhanging branch of a blossoming plum tree, watching over a hen and five chicks. The other has a rooster in a standoff with a weasel. In both, Shōson explored the textures and shapes of the roosters’ dramatic tail feathers and combs.
title: Rooster and Weasel
